description.narrative: Through a comprehensive approach, the Spotlight Initiative in Nigeria will aim to support a Nigeria where all women and girls are free from violence and harmful practices.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1. Laws and policies on VAWG/HP that adequately respond to the rights of all women and girls, including exercise/access to SRHR, are evidence-based and in line with international HR standards and treaty bodies’ recommendations.
2. Number of national and/or subnational evidence-based, costed and funded action plans and M&E frameworks on VAWG/SGBV/HP respond to the rights of all women and girls and are developed in a participatory manner (No.).
3. Number of key government decision makers with strengthened capacities to draft and cost action plans on ending VAWG, including SGBV/HP and the promotion of women and girls’ SRHR, and accompanying M&E frameworks.
4. Number of key government officials with increased awareness of human rights standards and obligations and strengthened capacities to develop laws and policies that guarantee the ability of women’s rights groups, CSOs and women human rights defenders to advance the human rights agenda.
5. Number of institutions that develop strategies, plans and/or programmes to prevent and respond to VAWG/SGBV/HP, including for those groups of women and girls facing intersecting and multiple forms of discrimination completed.

comment.narrative:
1. Yearly assessment of targeted institutions that have integrated gender equality and ending VAWG/SGBV/HP and the promotion of women and girls' SRHR in their curriculum completed.
2. Mapping/Situational/individual capacity assessment of key government staff with capacity to develop and deliver programs that prevent and respond to VAWG/SGBV/HP and integrate into development plans and the promotion of women and girl’s SRHR completed.
3. National & sub-national assessment & analysis of the budget allocation for prevention and elimination of all forms of VAWG/SGBV/HP Completed.
4. Review of the existing (National & sub-national) policies/laws against VAWG/SGBV/HP completed. Gap/SWOT analysis completed.
5. Quality prevalence and/or incidence data on VAWG/SGBV/HP is analyzed and made publicly available for the monitoring and reporting of the SDG target 5.2 indicators to inform evidence-based national decision-making processes, advocacy, and programming in Nigeria.

Legislative and policy frameworks, based on evidence and in line with international human rights standards, on all forms of violence against women and girls and harmful practices are in place and translated into plans
- National and sub-national systems and institutions plan, fund and deliver evidence-based programmes that prevent and respond to violence against women and girls and harmful practices, including in other sectors
- Partners (Parliamentarians, key government officials, CSOs and women’s rights advocates) at national and/or sub-national levels have greater knowledge, capacities, and tools on gender-responsive budgeting to end VAWG
- Relevant government authorities and women’s rights organizations at national and sub-national levels have better knowledge and capacity to deliver quality and coordinated essential services, including SRH services and access to justice, to women and girls’ survivors of violence, especially those facing multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination.
- Quality, disaggregated and globally comparable data on different forms of violence against women and girls and harmful practices, collected, analyzed, and used in line with international standards to inform laws, policies, and programmes.
- Womens rights groups, autonomous social movements and relevant CSOs, including those representing youth and groups facing multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination/marginalization, more effectively influence and advance progress on GEWE and ending VAWG.

- Under Outcome 1, 177 key government officials and 180 women human right defenders have increased awareness on human rights standards and obligations and strengthened capacities to develop laws and policies that guarantee the ability of women’s rights groups, CSOs and women human rights defenders to advance the human rights agenda. - Under Outcome 2, 28 key government officials and 261 women’s rights advocates have gained strengthened knowledge and capacities on gender-responsive budgeting to end VAWG/GBV/HP and to promote SRHR. 487 key government officials have also obtained enhanced capacities to develop and deliver programmes on VAWG/GBV/HP/SRHR. By building the capacity of both government partners and civil society, these training sessions are expected to enhance opportunities for an increased number of programmes in this area that are successfully planned, funded, and delivered. - Under Outcome 3, 31,586 persons have been directly reached and around 2,840,000 persons have been indirectly reached by campaigns and interventions transforming negative social norms and gender stereotyping that promote VAWG/HP/SGBV.
- On UNDP’s Livelihood integration pathway, empowering eighty seven (87) women and girls GBV survivors in different livelihood skill areas of their choice in 2020.
- Under Outcome 4, 215 women and girls’ survivors and their families have gained increased knowledge of and access to accompaniment and support services, including longer-term recovery services. 340 women and girls’ survivors of VAWG/SGBV/HP have increased knowledge and access to quality essential services.
- Under Outcome 5, the Spotlight Initiative has launched National Gender-Based Violence (GBV) Data Situation Rooms and Data Dashboard (Report GBV) in all project states. This has been adopted by the Ministry of Women Affairs and Social Development as the official national tool to collate data on Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG), GBV and Harmful Practices (HP). Consequently, 100 percent of the targeted states have a system to collate administrative data on VAWG/GBV/HP across different sectors. The establishment of a platform for harmonization of data on VAWG/GBV/HP has been a significant success to make quality, disaggregated and globally comparable data available in real-time to inform laws, policies, and programmes.
- 464 government personnel and other service providers from different sectors, have had their capacities strengthened to collate, and report data to the dashboard during 2020. Out of these, 324 have also enhanced their capacities to analyse, disseminate and use prevalence and/or incidence data on VAWG/GBV/HP. 398 women’s rights advocates have also gained strengthened capacities to collect and report data on VAWG/GBV/HP to the national tool. The large number of trained individuals ensures broad collation of data from various sources, as well as the sustainability of the dashboard over time.

The UNDP assisted National GBV Data Situation Room (NGDSR) created in 2020 has continued to serve as a platform for timely reporting and response to violence against women and girls. In 2021, 5,261 cases were reported on the platform while the Special Panel on SGBV led by National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) received over 139,780 complaints. The Panel sat in 7 states and determined 170 complaints.
- To enhance the success of the National GBV situation room, UNDP Nigeria in close collaboration with the Federal Ministry of Women Affairs inaugurated the Strategic Knowledge Management Technical Working Group on GBV. This has been followed with the quarterly Workshop on GBV – that brings together key players in the GBV programme monitoring and implementation. This activity directly contributed to ensuring expanding coverage of National GBV dashboard to all 36 states now.
- In collaboration with the Federal Ministry of Women Affairs, UNDP has supported the establishment of GBV data situation room across the 36 states of the federation to scale up of GBV data reportage to ensure that GBV data is well coordinated for National response. With UNDP leading this novel intervention, GBV data flows from the 36 states to the GBV data hub at the federal ministry of women Affairs. In addition, over 104 National Statistical Officers, government personnel, including service providers, from different sectors have their enhanced capacities to collect prevalence and/or incidence data, including qualitative data, on VAWG including SGBV/HP in line with international and regional standards.
- 20 NHRC Staff trained and continuous mentoring, monitoring on managing the CRM system. Increased visibility of National Human Rights Commission GBV Toll-free number in 4 Spotlight State leading to increase in reportage of violation cases.
- We have continued providing capacity building to the Police and capacitating Gender desks that have been set up in Police Stations to investigate cases of VAGW. Total number of 128 State Law Officers, staff of human rights institutions, justice sector and police Prosecutor’s capacity were strengthened on effective responses to Sexual Violence and Gender Based crimes against women and girls.
- In line with Leave No One Behind principle, UNDP developed a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for VAWG/SGBV/HP integrated service provision and strengthened referral pathways in Lagos State - Specifically for mainstreaming PWDS into the GBV response in Lagos state in collaboration with the Lagos State Office for Disability Affairs (LASODA).
- On UNDP’s Livelihood integration pathway, empowering one hundred and fifty (150) new beneficiaries in different livelihood skill areas of their choice (culinary 30, fashion design 46, make up 15, Professional caterer 7, Shoe making 2, cake making 22, hair dressing 25 and Event planning 3). This brings the cumulative number of survivors empowered in 2021 to [150]. The livelihood pathway programme is all inclusive with financial literacy, business registration and seed grants to transition beneficiaries from individuals to small business owners. This has promoted sustainable Livelihoods for Women hence contributing to decrease of incidence of violence against women.
- UNDP worked with Ministries of Women Affairs in Ebonyi and Cross River States to develop a new 5-year strategic plan aimed at ending violence against women and girls in line with Federal Ministry of Women Affairs mandate of protecting the interest of women and girls. This contributed to the achievement of Spotlight Initiative vision and mission of ending violence against women and girls and to the achievement of SDGs goal 5 in Nigeria.
- Organized a 16-day Novelty Football Match event to draw attention to SGBV Issues, over hundred persons (male and female) participated in the match to challenge violence against women and girls during 16th day of activism. Participants were drawn from EU, CSO’s, private and public sector.
- The federal ministry of women affairs with support from UNDP has developed a National GBV Accountability Framework with detailed responsibilities of key actors working in the GBV sector nationwide. This reinforced the FMWA mandate in coordinating GBV and provision of direction to key stakeholders on their responsibilities in the fight against all kind’s violence among women and girls, and provision of comprehensive quality services and make referrals easy for survivors.
- UNDP facilitated the official launch of the Ebonyi state GBV task force by the State Governor, (Engr. David Umahi) and signing of MoU between the State Ministry of Women Affairs, Ministry of Justice and law enforcement agencies to promote comprehensive, coordinated approach and formidable force to GBV prevention and response in Ebonyi State, as well as mainstreaming approaches across all sectors and levels, promote and create state and community level platforms for Legal services, support the development and coordination of a GBV referral pathway. This is a first of its kind in the State.
- Under the UNDP supported Presidential Special GBV Panel Enquiries led by the National Human Rights Commission in partnership with the Ministry of Justice and Nigeria Bar Association. The Commission has received over 139, 780 complaints on SBGV So far, hearings of the presidential SGBV panel was held in 8 states namely Ebonyi, Lagos, Cross River, Enugu, Rivers, Sokoto, Adamawa and the FCT, as a result 170 complaints was determined, and culprits was brought to account and victims compensated.
- We have been instrumental in the adoption of the VAPP bill in Adamawa State and Sokoto State. Through our advocacy efforts, trainings and engagement of key stakeholders, a great achievement recorded is the passage of the Violence against Persons Prohibition Law in the Sokoto State House of Assembly and finally assented by the Governor. The achievement is, the Sokoto State VAPP Bill which has been passed by the State House of Assembly and assented to by the Governor and has become the Sokoto State VAPP Law being a legal framework based on evidence and international human rights standards prohibiting all forms of violence against women.
- Leveraging on established community advocacy platforms, we have continued to train women, girls, men and boys to work as lead advocates/community mobilisers in their communities to promote positive gender equitable norms, attitudes and behaviors in the Spotlight States: we were able to reach out to 17,510 women as a result of this who have come forward for assistance and have been referred for support. The community platforms have engaged with different groups (women, adolescent girls, and boys) in the communities to increase knowledge of and access to services for women and girls, including groups facing multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination.
- We support Ministry of Women Affairs to coordinate work of CSOs at Federal and State Level that are working on VAWG. This is supporting overall prevention and response activities across all Spotlight States. Consequently, the federal ministry of women affairs with support from UNDP has developed and launched a National GBV Accountability Framework with detailed responsibilities of key actors working in the GBV sector nationwide.
